Listen, we don't live in a perfect world. One day we will. Isn't that awesome? One day we're going to be with the Lord for all of eternity. But right now we don't live in a perfect world. And in this world that's not perfect, there's problems. And there's divisions and schisms and there's things that happen. And he says, the spiritual one is to be able to judge. Did Moses judge? He did. Jethro said, this is no good. Why? It's consuming you. So what do they do? They got other men that would be able to judge the smaller matters. Right? That's what happened in the Old Testament, right? We don't have time to go, it's 656, we don't have time to go back there and look at all of it. But you understand, that's what happened in the Old Testament. And they got these people involved, these spiritual people involved that could take the Word of God, the truth that God had given at that particular time, and say, here, this is the standard by which we judge. Right? That's what happened. And so we find that as we come to the New Testament, and Jesus says, judge not, there in Matthew chapter number 6. 7, it's not the way that people use it today running around saying, you guys can't judge me. The Bible says judge not. Read the whole context and understand the entirety of God's Word. Now if you're running around judging people and you're not letting God judge you, and you're not using this book as a standard in your life, thou hypocrite. That's what the Bible says. And so we first use God's Word to examine ourselves. God, I want to please you with my life. How do I do that? What do I do? Oh, when the Word of God is read in your daily devotions, when the Word of God is preached, when we hear it in whatever context we hear it, we sit around a table and have fellowship and maybe there's some spiritual conversation that's taking place and the Word of God is used and God pricks our heart with regard to something that needs to be dealt with in our lives, we deal with it. And we know that with Him there's forgiveness and there's restoration. We can rejoice in that. But just as there's forgiveness and restoration for me, there's forgiveness and restoration for everyone else. Isn't that awesome? And we've got to be so thankful for that. So I hope as we look at the context of Matthew 7, 1 through 5, coupled with 1 Corinthians 5 and 6, it helps us to have a better understanding of this portion of Scripture and so often what we hear people saying to us today of judge not. I'm thankful that God's given us a standard, a standard that is perfect. See you're not perfect and neither am I. How many times even in a court of law the judge rules in a certain way and you say, how did they rule that way? This book is perfect and when we use this book we can have righteous judgment. Let's pray. Father we love You. We thank You for loving us. We thank You for the truth of Your Word, for the power of Your Word. God I pray that we'd leave here this evening not with a misunderstanding that we're to go out and judge everybody. Lord help us to have a proper understanding that there's this balance and that first Lord we would come humbly before Thy throne and ask You to examine us and that we'd examine ourselves by the right standard, the Word of God. And that we'd be honest and we'd be humble before You and before Your Word. God You'd help us to deal with any sin in our lives that needs to be dealt with. Lord that You'd help us to please You that we would not be hypocrites. Lord I pray that You would use us to help others in their spiritual journey. Not in a condemning or condescending type of a way but in a way of trying to help and to provide sweet fellowship, forgiveness and restoration. Lord I pray that You'd help us to take truth from Your Word tonight that would help us in our daily behavior. We pray that in these moments of invitation that You'd have Your will in way. We pray that decisions would be made that would please Thee and we'll thank You for it in Christ's name we pray.

segments.text: Getting back here this evening to our Ask the Pastor series in Matthew chapter 7, we'll
be looking at verses 1 through 5, and then we'll be looking over in the book of 1 Corinthians
as well this evening.
But here in Matthew chapter 7, we'll be looking at these first five verses.
If you have a bulletin today, you see that the title for the message comes from verse
number 1, really the entirety of verse number 1, Judge not that ye be not judged.

it's in reference to misquoted or misunderstood Bible verses, and they provide a few examples
on that particular question.
And this is one of the questions, the first, or one of the verses, the first of the examples
that was listed on the particular question that was submitted was Matthew 7, 1, and we'll
examine this portion of Scripture this evening.
Before we dive into the passage of Scripture, there's some things that I think are important
for us to remember and to be aware of when we think about our approach to the Word of
God as we read the Bible, as we study the Bible, we must take great care to properly
interpret and apply the Bible.
And we understand that no prophecy is of any private interpretation.
We read that in the New Testament.
We understand that we're to compare Scripture with Scripture.
Someone said this, that the best commentary on the Bible is the Bible.
Many times people will talk about and use commentaries, and I'm not suggesting that
it's an evil thing to use commentaries, but really commentaries are what man's thoughts
are on the Word of God.
And there's some commentaries that are beneficial, that are helpful, that you can have as a resource,
but I would always encourage, and I try to follow this pattern in my own life, is to
study the Scriptures, and study the Scriptures, and study the Scriptures, and if you might
go to a commentary at some point, it's not the first thing you do, let me read what this
person said and then let me go back to the Bible.
It's to search the Scriptures, to interpret, comparing Scripture with Scripture.
And so let me just give you a few thoughts with regard to the importance of taking and
properly interpreting and applying the Bible.
Number one is this, context is critical.
Context is critical.
So often where error creeps in is when text of Scripture is taken out of its context.
And we take and we talk about preaching, we talk about topical preaching, exegetical preaching,
and expository preaching, and taking and using a context.
Typically I preach exegetical, expository type of messages, that's my style of preaching.
But to isogaze is to take a verse and to take it out of context, and it's a problem.
I mentioned already, but the second thought is to interpret Scripture with Scripture.
And then the third thought is this, that we must resist the temptation to over-spiritualize
what the Bible says.

really there in the Bible, and so those are some important things.
